componenttext: David, I think it's just confidence in the strategy that we've been executing, the changes that we've made to our business model are what you're -- is what you're seeing in the results that we're delivering. And also, you're seeing that particularly in the strength of our North America business. And I think when we look at what we see in that business, the improvements that we're making there and we look also at some of the other elements around the world, that gave us the confidence to make that statement to say that we're tracking to that range.

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair. And then on winter tire inventories in Europe, obviously, we've seen that sell-in has been poor. I think it was on top of a pretty high single-digit sell-in last year. Where do you think the inventories are now as it relates to potentia
componenttext: Okay, that's fair. And then on winter tire inventories in Europe, obviously, we've seen that sell-in has been poor. I think it was on top of a pretty high single-digit sell-in last year. Where do you think the inventories are now as it relates to potentially cold winter here? Do you think the easy comp from last year is going to set up for a particularly strong quarter in the event that we do see a little bit more of a normalized winter in Europe?

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: David, it's a good question. And I -- if I just maybe take a step back for one second, the winter market is important to the industry there. It's around about 30% of the tires we sell. It's typically high-end tires and it's very good mix, so forth. So it'
componenttext: David, it's a good question. And I -- if I just maybe take a step back for one second, the winter market is important to the industry there. It's around about 30% of the tires we sell. It's typically high-end tires and it's very good mix, so forth. So it's very important to us. And as you know, we're a leader in winter technology. The situation that we're seeing, as you know, coming off of 3 warm winters in a row, and as Laura mentioned and I think as we said in the past, we've kind of planned for that sort of green winter even though we've seen some snow at this point. And part of what goes into our thinking is pretty much in line is what you're saying. You can almost call it the sort of the animal spirits of the winter or the channel in Europe right now, particularly in Germany. They do have higher inventory in the channel right now. And on top of that, you've had these 3 warm winters, so there's little motivation to go stock up and go long on tires. The industry is typically around 100 million units, something like that, if you do the math. We would say that with higher inventory in the channel, that's obviously still a question as to whether it can even reach that level. It's clearly been much higher than that if you go back to the white winters of 2011. It was actually much higher than what I'm saying. So as we look at it, we are going to continue to sort of stay in a cautious view. We think we're very well prepared for it. I went through on my remarks, our winter lineup, our Ultra Grip Performance tire, our Dunlop Winter Sport 5, our Vector 4Season for those that want to move to all season, that's a small market. But we have top-tier winning podium products in all of those categories right now, so we're ready. I think what would give us a boost, what would give the industry a boost, frankly, is cold weather and snow as we head into November here.

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just to summarize that, it sounds as if there is upside to the $2 billion if there is in fact a colder or normalized winter in Europe?

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think unequivocally, we could say that. And it's kind of as we look at the winter, it's kind of like interest rates. We think they're going to go up and they don't. We think it's going to snow and it hasn't. So it's -- we got to wait for the event to happen and then we'll see what happens. But clearly, if it snows, I -- there's absolutely a virtuous effect to that.

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then maybe just last one for me. For the online sales channel, we've seen a little bit of a small arms race here as Michelin's bought a few in Europe. They've also rolled out an on-demand service in the U.S. And then Bridgestone more recen
componenttext: Understood. And then maybe just last one for me. For the online sales channel, we've seen a little bit of a small arms race here as Michelin's bought a few in Europe. They've also rolled out an on-demand service in the U.S. And then Bridgestone more recently bought some distribution channels in both brick-and-mortar as well online over this past weekend. How do you see that online e-commerce distribution channel evolving over the coming couple of years for the -- really, for the global big 3?

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think number one, it's really confirmation of the strategy that we rolled out earlier in the year. And I think that's important. That's what we saw coming. It's why we did what we did. And I would tell you, we took a long time in getting there, bui
componenttext: Yes. I think number one, it's really confirmation of the strategy that we rolled out earlier in the year. And I think that's important. That's what we saw coming. It's why we did what we did. And I would tell you, we took a long time in getting there, building up what you've heard me say, our brand and building up search on our brand. We're the #1 searched tire brand, tire manufacturer in the U.S., rivaling some other big online tire sellers right now and doing that as a manufacturer. We are significantly ahead of our -- of others, let's just say. And we did that very consciously to create the demand in the marketplace. Then we pulled together signing up our partner dealers and also putting the distribution capabilities in place and then marrying the technology to be able to make that work so a customer has a good experience as we're doing this really to make the tire buying process easier for the consumer. What I said, I said very simply, but it's a very complex problem. And it's one of those things that sort of bolt-ons don't necessarily make the process that less -- have that much less friction and it's because you got to hook up all kinds of things in the back. So this is not an easy thing to do to get the SKU explosion, to get the right tire to the right place at the right time when a consumer is going online to buy that tire. So this is not an easy process, and it's why we're being very methodical and having a good success as we go at this point. Having said that, I do think, like most other products and particularly around millennials being the consumers with $1 trillion of buying power with some 80 million millennials out there, that this will be an absolute way to buy tires, an expected way to buy tires because that's how that group does commerce to a large degree. So having a formula that works out there and being able to marry it with the brand and importantly, the distribution, both retailers and aligned distributors to get the tires there, is going to be what wins and that's how we're thinking about it, sort of building it from the bottom up to be able to deliver on that value promise. And so far, we feel very good about it. But there's no question, it will be a way that consumers want to shop, and Goodyear and its partners, partner dealers are getting ready for that.

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's actually Pat Nolan on for Rod. Quick -- 2 quick questions on North America. First, on the supply issues you alluded to in Q3, is that something you see being resolved near term? In other words, will you be able to perform in line with the industry ov
componenttext: It's actually Pat Nolan on for Rod. Quick -- 2 quick questions on North America. First, on the supply issues you alluded to in Q3, is that something you see being resolved near term? In other words, will you be able to perform in line with the industry over the next couple of quarters? Or do you think these supply issues constrain you a bit there? And secondly, maybe Rich, if you can expand on your view on the sustainability of this North American margin performance. I mean, it's a multiple of what the historic level has been. Maybe if you can just expand on how sustainable you think these margins are.

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the first question on the way to catch up on supply, I would tell you, this is a point that we've been making relative to supplying those high-end HVA complex tires. Think the larger rim diameter, SUV tires, in particular, were performance tires.
componenttext: Sure. So the first question on the way to catch up on supply, I would tell you, this is a point that we've been making relative to supplying those high-end HVA complex tires. Think the larger rim diameter, SUV tires, in particular, were performance tires. And those are tires that remain high in demand. The capacity for those tires, on a broad basis, still, I would say, is behind the demand for those tires. And that's something we are working to continue to make more of and doing that by getting more tires out of our existing factories, investing in our North American factories and also using our sort of lower demands around the world to import some of those tires in. So in the near term, that's how we're trying to catch up and continue to be a better supplier. Over the long term, that's also why we embarked on the Americas plant that we've talked on in the past. So that's something that will take some time to put in place. It also is going to be a function of the demand that's out there as well. We think that the demand will be there, and we're going to work -- we are working feverishly to do that, keeping our factories running full to be able to supply those tires. I would also say though, just to put it in perspective, that part of that market continues to grow. The other parts of the market, as we said, are always subject to these imports coming in. Remember, we had these big gyrations because buying ahead of tariffs and the like. And you have to remember, as that drives the market or has an impact on the market, it has -- it impacts us less as we're focused on other segments of the market and not so much what's happening in the lower end. The question on the sustainability of North America's market -- excuse me, margins, I would say, as we look at the business today, we remain -- the industry today, we remain very optimistic and positive on what's still available for us to go achieve. I just mentioned the demand for HVA tires out there. I made a few remarks earlier about the opportunities related to growing through digital. And as we look at our business, the tire business is really one of execution. Right tire, right place, right time, creating the right demand and having a brand that brings consumers to the stores and to our participating dealers. By doing those things right, and as I said, working and executing at the intersection of innovation of demand creation and of supply, we see continued opportunity to continue to grow our business. So we as we look at the earnings power of North America and we look at the industry conditions out there, I still remain very confident in the ability -- in the earnings ability of our North America business.

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And when you add on the continued operational excellence initiatives that drive the cost, that's not fully rolled out through all of our factories, even in North America, through all the workstations. And then I'd probably say, maybe to the earlier q
componenttext: Yes. And when you add on the continued operational excellence initiatives that drive the cost, that's not fully rolled out through all of our factories, even in North America, through all the workstations. And then I'd probably say, maybe to the earlier question, we live it every day, but don't forget about how complex these tires are, right, the complexity that's part of the equation. I would say that we are seeing probably demand higher than our expectations for the really highly complex tires, the performance and the SUV tires as well, and that continues to really put pressure on supply as we go.

componenttext: So I guess, I would say for raw materials year-over-year in 2016, we do see overall low single-digit improvement. headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a few more for me. I think Latin America is one of the concerns here, specifically Venezuela. It sounds as if you guys have continued to be able to transact at one of the favorable SICAD rates. I mean, how much longer do you think that continues and
componenttext: Just a few more for me. I think Latin America is one of the concerns here, specifically Venezuela. It sounds as if you guys have continued to be able to transact at one of the favorable SICAD rates. I mean, how much longer do you think that continues and you'll be able to get U.S. dollars to buy raw materials down there? Because just thinking about the quarter and the year, Venezuela has been a meaningful contributor to earnings. And I guess, the thought going forward is, how much longer can that continue in your view?

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. David, just a quick comment on Latin America. In general, very difficult environment down there, particularly in Brazil. I know your question is on Venezuela. But I will just take the opportunity that our teams have been executing well down there in
componenttext: Yes. David, just a quick comment on Latin America. In general, very difficult environment down there, particularly in Brazil. I know your question is on Venezuela. But I will just take the opportunity that our teams have been executing well down there in light of consumer OE business and the truck business there that's down 20% plus. And as you see from our numbers, we grew volume above 20% in consumer replacement volume, above 20% in virtually all our key countries down there. So the team is executing well there, in what is a very difficult environment around currency and inflation and devaluation in general, excluding Venezuela. So we're pleased with how we're doing, but we clearly see the headwinds going on there. And Venezuela, it clearly is one of them. And I'll have Laura address your questions in particular.

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, David. So when you think about it, for us and for tires, tires are being treated as a priority good right now. There's very few forms of transportation in the country, and we continue to have access to U.S. dollars to buy those raw materials, a
componenttext: Yes. Sure, David. So when you think about it, for us and for tires, tires are being treated as a priority good right now. There's very few forms of transportation in the country, and we continue to have access to U.S. dollars to buy those raw materials, as I mentioned. We've just received $15 million in the third quarter. Now line of sight is limited. Each company's facts and circumstances are very different, but we continue to make and sell tires in their -- in high demand. We certainly have a tremendous amount of disclosure related to Venezuela in all our Qs and Ks. But for us, we continue to operate the business under normal course, and really predicting kind of the future is very difficult for Venezuela.

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair. And I guess, maybe on that topic, when you think about the hyperinflation down there, how conservative have you been in your updated outlook and kind of SOI walk for inflation? I mean, it -- could it be something that get -- again, for
componenttext: Okay, that's fair. And I guess, maybe on that topic, when you think about the hyperinflation down there, how conservative have you been in your updated outlook and kind of SOI walk for inflation? I mean, it -- could it be something that get -- again, for the fourth quarter, becomes -- comes in a little bit higher and ends up really eating into and making the cost savings minus inflation a negative? Or do you think you've been accurate on your estimates for fourth Q?

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, for us, that about $20 million in the fourth quarter really takes into consideration the December elections. And that historically -- and I think everyone would expect that to create even more volatility as we go than what's in the third quar
componenttext: Yes. I mean, for us, that about $20 million in the fourth quarter really takes into consideration the December elections. And that historically -- and I think everyone would expect that to create even more volatility as we go than what's in the third quarter. So for us, we see it as a balanced estimate for the fourth quarter.

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And David, I would say, for your question on cost savings, I mean, we feel, if you exclude Venezuela, which we tried to do, we are pretty much on our sort of forecast of cost savings, if not actually exceeding it. So if you strip Venezuela out, and i
componenttext: Yes. And David, I would say, for your question on cost savings, I mean, we feel, if you exclude Venezuela, which we tried to do, we are pretty much on our sort of forecast of cost savings, if not actually exceeding it. So if you strip Venezuela out, and it certainly does sort of complicate things -- but when you take it away, I would say we're executing very well against those cost savings. If that was an underlying question as well, we feel pretty good about the core business.

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Yes. And as you -- we have been able to work through the inflation increases. Even if we have some impact further in our cost savings versus inflation, we -- it tends to be offset in the price/mix versus raws for Venezuela.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just lastly, with your analogy earlier, you were talking about the potential rising interest rates that we've all been kind of waiting to see here. Is there any update when you think about your balance sheet and the structure in terms of timing of maybe coming to the market and looking at refinancing some of that higher coupon debt that's out there? I know a couple of them became callable. Or one has become callable and a few more in the next year?

headline: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we always monitoring our capital structure and we take a very proactive approach to managing our interest expense and we'll continue to do that. Now we obviously can't talk about or comment when we would be in the market or not. But that is our history
componenttext: So we always monitoring our capital structure and we take a very proactive approach to managing our interest expense and we'll continue to do that. Now we obviously can't talk about or comment when we would be in the market or not. But that is our history and you've seen it recently, right? In May, we amended and restated our European revolving credit facility and I think it was a 75 basis point reduction. June, we amended the U.S. second lien term loan and lowered that by about 100 basis points. So that's kind of been our MO of the past.
